citations.narrative:
A review of facility records identified a lack of disposition records for several animals that had passed since the last
inspection: 3 serval kits, 3 fennec fox kits, a ring-tailed lemur and a hybrid lemur. Complete disposition records are
required for compliance with animal welfare regulations. Correct by maintaining records of disposition for any animal
exhibited at the facility.

In the enclosure housing two servals, a wooden support bean extending along the top of the fence had cracked and left
large jagged pieces of wood exposed.
In the enclosure housing one caracal, there was a splintered wooden platform that was beginning to reveal exposed
screws near the edge of the platform.
In the enclosure housing a lion and tiger, the back board of a wooden den had detached from the bottom of the structure.
Additionally, a perch platform was noted to be leaning at odd angle. In the same enclosure, a plastic enrichment barrel
had exposed sharp edges from sustained use by the animals.
Wearing wood and poorly maintained structures or objects within primary enclosures can cause injury to the animals if not
regularly maintained. Outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to
protect the animals from injury and contain the animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee and authorized persons.
Additional Inspectors:
KRISTIN NAPOLIEnd Section

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
A review of facility records identified a lack of disposition records for several animals that had passed since the last 
inspection: 3 serval kits, 3 fennec fox kits, a ring-tailed lemur and a hybrid lemur. Complete disposition records are 
required for compliance with animal welfare regulations. Correct by maintaining records of disposition for any animal 
exhibited at the facility. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
In the enclosure housing two servals, a wooden support bean extending along the top of the fence had cracked and left 
large jagged pieces of wood exposed. 
In the enclosure housing one caracal, there was a splintered wooden platform that was beginning to reveal exposed 
screws near the edge of the platform. 
In the enclosure housing a lion and tiger, the back board of a wooden den had detached from the bottom of the structure. 
Additionally, a perch platform was noted to be leaning at odd angle. In the same enclosure, a plastic enrichment barrel 
had exposed sharp edges from sustained use by the animals. 
Wearing wood and poorly maintained structures or objects within primary enclosures can cause injury to the animals if not

regularly maintained. Outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to 
protect the animals from injury and contain the animals. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee and authorized persons. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KRISTIN NAPOLIEnd Section
